resources.string: Easy way to mantain your Diet!
Best exercise suggestions for you to make you fit!

1.Fruits – Banana
2.Vegetables - Rajma,paneer
3.Protein – Avoid eating any protein source such as meat, eggs, fish, beans, lentils, and mushrooms.
4.Fats and Oils – Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
5.Carbs – Avoid all carb rich foods, including brown rice.
1. It is advisable to eat one apple and drink a of glass of water for breakfast.\n2. 8 to 12 glasses of water.

1. Eating baked potatoes will help you go through this hard phase. you can also switch to cabbage soup or tomato soup and have it for lunch or dinner.\n2. Roasted chana is a low calorie snack that you can include in your weight loss diet. It is a perfect teatime snack and can be savoured in the form of a chaat as well. Roasted chana not only helps in managing weight but is also loaded with health benefiting properties.\n3. 8 to 12 glasses of water.

1.Fruits – Avoid all fruits on this day.
2.Vegetables - Rajma,paneer
3.Protein – Avoid eating any protein source such as meat, eggs, fish, beans, lentils, and mushrooms.
4.Fats and Oils – Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
5.Carbs – Avoid all carb rich foods, including brown rice.

Vegetables – Avoid all pulses, rajma, panner etc on this day.
Fruits– Avoid eating bananas.
Protein – Avoid eating any protein source such as meat, eggs, fish, beans, lentils, and mushrooms.
Fats and Oils– Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
Carbs– Avoid all carb-rich foods, including brown rice.
Dairy – Full fat milk, full fat yogurt, frozen yogurt, ice cream, and cheese.
1. You can include fruits for breakfast and finish it off with fresh vegetables in the evening. \n2. 8 to 12 glasses of water

Vegetables – Potato and sweet potato.
Fruits – Avoid eating all fruits except banana.
Protein – Avoid eating any protein source such as meat, eggs, fish, beans, lentils, and mushrooms.
Fats and Oils – Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
Carbs – Avoid all carb-rich foods, including brown rice.
Dairy – Full fat milk, full fat yogurt, frozen yogurt, ice cream, and cheese.

1.Bananas provide instant energy. They are rich in pectin, which aids digestion. They are also high in potassium and low in salt\n2.Milk is a great source of calcium and potassium.\n3.8 to 12 glasses of water.

Vegetables– Potato and sweet potato.
Fruits– Banana.
Protein– Beef, pork, and turkey.
Fats and Oils – Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
Carbs – White rice, bread, and processed foods.
Dairy – Full fat milk, full fat yogurt, frozen yogurt, ice cream, and cheese.

1.The benefits of eating oatmeal include lowering your risk of heart disease and colorectal cancer. Whole grains like oats can also help reduce blood pressure and aid in digestion.\n3.8 to 12 glasses of water.

Vegetables – Sweet potato and potato.
Fruits – Try to avoid fruits, especially mango, banana, and cherry.
protein – Beef, pork, and turkey.
Fats and Oils – Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
Carbs – White rice, bread, and processed foods.
Dairy – Full fat milk, full fat yogurt, frozen yogurt, ice cream, and cheese.
1.Vegetables have to be boiled, not fried, and salads shouldn’t have any heavy dressings.\n3.8 to 12 glasses of water.

Vegetables – Potato and sweet potato.
Fruits – Banana, cherry, mango, and pear.
Protein – Avoid any kind of meat such as beef, turkey, chicken, pork, fish and lentils, beans, soy, and mushrooms.
Fats and Oils – Lard, butter, margarine, and safflower oil.
Carbs – White rice, bread, and processed foods.
Dairy – Full fat milk, full fat yogurt, frozen yogurt, ice cream, and cheese.

1.Include vegetables like cabbage or broccoli to go with the brown rice.\n2.Fruit juices will flush out the toxins from the system, and the other food items will provide you with the much-needed energy.\n3.8 to 12 glasses of water.
1.Do not resort to eating highly processed junk foods to get your extra calories. \n2. 8 to 12 glass of water.

Diabetes is a chronic disease which is related to metabolic,in which oxidation of carbohydrates and glucose is not fully detected. it is a is a chronic metabolic disorder in which the body fails to convert sugars, starches and other foods into energy.

1. Extreme thirst
 2. Extreme hunger
 3. blurred vision
 4. unexpected weight loss
 5. Extreme tiredness
 6. numbness or tingling in the feet or hands
 7. Dry, itchy skin
One teaspoon of fenugreek (methi)\n powder + water.

1. Sugar
2. Salt
3. Fat
4. Whole milk products
5. Tea and coffee
6. White flour and its products
7. Avoid white rice, potatoes, carrots, breads and banana because they increase the blood-sugar levels.

1.35-40 minute faster walk every day.
2.Diabetic person should eat food between times intervals like take breakfast in morning, lunch, some snakes and dinner.
3/Avoid oily food.
4.Diabetic person should eat food slowly.
1.Eat lots of fruit and veg.\n2.Drink 8 to 12 glass of water.

1.Begin by standing with your legs straight and your arms to your sides.\n2/Jump up and spread your feet beyond hip-width apart while bringing your arms above your head, nearly touching.\n3.Jump again, lowering your arms and bringing your legs together. Return to your starting position.

1.Stand with your back straight.
2.Keep your feet together.
3.Now jump on the ground a few inches letting the rope pass under your feet and bring it back up.
4.Repeat this step for 10 to 15 minutes.

1.Step on the peddles and get hold of the handlebars firmly.\n2.Now move your feet along the peddles as if you are stepping forward, it seems just like the walking motion.\n3.With every step, make sure you move handlebars also, one towards your chest and alternating the movement.

1.First of all sit with your legs straight in front of you.
2.Bring your arms forward and join your hands.
3.Now start making a big clockwise circle like you are grinding milk.
4.Do 10-15 reps clockwise and then anti-clockwise.
1.Stand with feet apart and bend slightly forward.\n2.Join your hands in front of you.\n3.Now start moving your feet as fast as you can in a wide-leg jogging.

1.Begin with a high plank position with your hands firmly placed on the ground, right beneath your shoulders.\n2.Now keeping a neutral spine, lower down your body until your chest is just above the floor.\n3.Push yourself back up to complete one rep.

1.Stand with your legs shoulder width apart. Keep your hands clasped together in front of your chest.\n2.Begin the downward motion by flexing your knees and hips. Sit back with your hips and keep an upright torso.\n3.Go full depth and return to starting position to finish one rep.

1.Stand with your mid-foot under the barbell.
2.Bend over and grab the bar with a shoulder-width grip.
3.Bend your knees until your shins touch the bar.
4.Lift your chest up and straighten your lower back.
5.Take a big breath, hold it, and stand up with the weight

1.Lie flat on your back on a bench.
2.Grip the bar with hands just wider than shoulder-width apart, so when you’re at the bottom of your move your hands are directly above your elbows. This allows for maximum force generation.
3.Bring the bar slowly down to your chest as you breathe in.
4.Push up as you breathe out, gripping the bar hard and watching a spot on the ceiling rather than the bar, so you can ensure it travels the same path every time.

1.Grab a pull-up bar with your palms facing outwards.
2.Pull yourself up slightly over the bar by keeping a slight arch in your back and torso puffed out.
3.Slowly lower down yourself until your arms are fully extended.
4.That’s rep one, Do as many strict reps you can do.

1. Put your right leg high up on your left thigh.
2. After you maintain a steady balance, inhale slowly and join your palms together above your head.
3. Make sure that your spine and left leg are straight.
4.As you exhale, bring your hands down and put your right leg on the ground.

1.Sit up with your back straight and toes pointed outwards.
2. Stretch your hands upwards as you breathe in, while exhaling, slowly bring your hands down and try to touch your toes.
3. Place your hands wherever they reach and try to stay in the position for as long as comfortable.
4. Do not force yourself. Slowly release your hold and stretch your spine.
5.Repeat another 5 times with the same breathing process.

1.Stand on the mat straight and in relaxed position.
2.Bring your legs together keeping just a few inches distance from one another.
3.Now bend forward and touch your ankles with your hand. Keep forehead positioned in front of your knees.
4.If you are a beginner, Do not force yourself. Just bend your knees a bit and touch your ankles.

1.Sit on the floor with bent knees. They should be separated from one another. Your hips should be resting on your heels.
2.Place your hands on your thighs.
3.Now start bending forward such that the upper torso is on your thighs.
4.Bend further down to make your forehead touch the ground.
5.Bring your hands back and let them lie freely on the ground beside your feet with palms facing the ceiling or you may also hold your heels with your hands.

1.Start with sitting cross-legged, i.e. with left leg on the right thigh and right leg on the left thigh.\n2. Keep your spine straight and put your hands on your knees, you may use a mudra if you like (join the tip of your index finger with the tip of your thumb).The spine remains erect and the breathing is normal.

1.First stand straight with your ankles and hang your arms behind your torso.\n2. Balance your body weight on your body after raising your ankles and landing them on the floor.\n3. As you inhale, lift your ankles and release your shoulder blades away from your head.

1.Always sit in Sukhasana with your hands resting sideways on the knees.
2.You can also sit in Padmasana.
3.If you begin from the left then close the right nostril with your right thumb and inhale slowly to fill up your lungs.
4.Now, exhale slowly from the right nostril.
5.It is essential to focus on your breath and practice the technique slowly.
6.Repeat 60 times or for 5 minutes. You can do this any time of the day.
7.Ensure that your back is straight and shoulders relaxed while you perform the pranayam.
